Having established his major premise, and having fixed the percentage of the mortgage debt at 8.9 %, Dr. Eid next turns his attention to the effect and influences of a mortgage debt on the economical development of the country.

The economical development of Egypt owes its birth to Mehemet Ali and much of its sub- sequent growth to the Khedive Ismail who for all his extravagances must be reckoned in many ways economically as a factor for good in Egyptian agricultural history: the first barrage and many of the major canals of today are stand­ing witness of his endeavours and successes.
But when the inevitable crash came its ultimate result was to break up the large holding in course of time we have already explained in dealing with the Dumsins and Daira Sanitb)

and to put them in the hands of the most proper owners. the actual titles of the sol , who like the yeomen of old-time in England may truly be considered the backbone of the country. To the number of these who became proprietors on the breakdown of Ismail finances must now be added all who have bought land from the Credit Foucier and those other institutions that obtained barren land from the Government converted it into agricul- tural properties, and re-sold it at a comfortable profit. So that to-day as compared with 80 years ago the number of peasant proprietors is enormous. It is profitable therefore to cor aider if thia large body of persons receive a benefit or the reverse from the money they borrow on mortgage.

To answer the second question we must first decide the average rate of interest co mortgage money, end as not even the banks publish this it is difficult to fix it accurately. The conventional maximum in Egypt is 9% and the Agricultural bank, which charges the highest rate owing to the smallness its loans and the comparative shortness of their dura- tion, bee now dropped it. rate from 9% to 8%. But on ventes e teime the rate probably varies from 4% to 5%. Dr. Eid, after careful consideration, fixes on the following rate, as forming the average rate, to-day: 6.2% for the Bank., 5 for assurance end other companies,

8 for private individuals, and 5 for rentes & tormer, whereas in 1895 the average rate was. at least 8% all round. If then, as is the cure, the amount of the mortgage debt daring s leal ten years baa increased by 254% the amount paid as charges thereon has only shown an increase of 194%. 'Meanwhile daring those years the exports of the country, well called ‘lo miroir par excellence do dere'opment doouomiqae," shows an increase of 70%. while all the time taxation of all aorta has been diminishing.

But possibly ell these generalisations ate not applicable to any given cases. Let us there­fore take the example of a total mortgage effected first by the proprietor of a email holding of 5-feddans and second of a somewhat larger holding of say 50 feddans and let us see how heavily the burden of high debt weighs upon the mortgager, In the first place, to replace moneys by the produce of the soil takes at least 15 years and that that is fully recognised is shown by the fact that the Agri­cultural Bank lately advanced its maximum period from 15 to 20 years and that the average duration,of a loan granted by the other banks is 19 years.

Now let us assume the value of our land at L.E. 100 a feddan, giving in the first instance a total of L.E. 500 On this the banks will advance up to 60 % of its value, say, LE 300, end putting the rate at its highest, let us say at 7 % plus l. % for expenses. To repay this in 15 years, Dr. Eid estimates will require an ■ amortisation fund of LE 28 to L.E 34 per annum, and as the soil in Egypt gives a return of at • least 7 % our tellah mortgager makes LE 35 per annum and at the same time lives off his land. Thus at the end of 15 years he will stand quit of his debt with a minimum of £15 set aside, and during those fifteen years it must not be forgotten that he has supported himself and bit family on the produce of the lend, besides making some profit on what we may call bye-products such as milk, eggs, chickens, goats and the like, which are mainly self-supporting and find their own sustenance at best they can. In troth, LB. 15 in. 15 years - is not wealth, but for the Egyptian peasant it is as far removed from destination as it is from riches according to the European standpoint. Finally we mast remember that at the end of the period he 'is possessed of a property improved to the value of the mort­gage money sank therein and of 15 years' constant labor spent thereon.

The larger the property the greater the amount that can be putby; for the interest is re- funded and the term extended as that our pro­prietor of 50 feddene cf similar value on a total mortgage amounting to somewhere between LE 8,500 and LE 3 000 at 7 % all told would have to set aside an amortisation fund of be tween L.E 235 and LE 280 per annum, and would gain from his laud L.E 350, leaving the comparatively comfortable margin of L.E. 70 to LE 115 per annum. And as a further proof that the fellaheen are not weighed down by a burden of debt,a study of the number of expro­priations renders the matter quite clear. In 1897 those amounted to 266. while in 1905 bey were but 110 and of these the majority represent the results of the execution of judge -ments given in transactions other than mort­gage transactions.

Finally Dr. Bid draws hit conclusions from all these carefully compiled and well-arranged statistics. The mortgage debt of Egypt is lower io proportion than that of any other civilised country, and that not withstanding the fact that from the fertility of its soil Egypt is fitted to boar an unusually heavy mortgage debt without inconvenience But the time, Dr. Eid thinks, has now come to pause a little and consolidate what is already under cultivation, rather than seek to extend the area of fertility ; and that the Government think alike with Dr. Eid on this point is proved by 'be fact that the water0 the main or sole source of Egypt's fertility—is now being employed in improvements rather than in extensions and in perfecting whet is already began rather than in attempting any new undertakings. div.p: G.. VIVIAN VERNON.

It is with sincere regret that we have to record the death of Mr. G. Vivian Vernon. Mr. Vernon first came to Egypt between seven and eight years ago, when he was on the staff of Sir John Aird and Co. On the completion of the works at Assouan Mr. Vernon com menced business in Alexandria, and for the last two years be had been manager and director of the British Engineering Company. His death occurred on Saturday at the Deaconesse Hospital, after a long and painful illness. His death, at the early age of 38, will be regretted by a wide circle of friends. The funeral took yesterday, the service being conducted by the Rev. A.H. Longley.

FEHIM PASHA.
TERRORISING CONSTANTINOPLE
Constantinople, February 8.

Baron Marschall de Beiberstein was received in audience by the Sultan. The crimes of Fehim Pasha were the chief subject of the conversation, and as a result his Majesty has ordered the formation of a special com- mission at Yildiz to examine the chargee. Fehim Pasha has become an object of terror to everybody. In the meanwhile he parades the city ostentatiously. (Reuter

It is with a certain measure of relief that we hear of the action taken by the German Em­bassy at Constantinople to punish Fehim Pasha chief of the Hafirh. Thia functionary has thus far enjoyed immunity owing to the fact of his being son of the foster-brother of the Sultan, and therefore a privileged bosom ser- pent. A worthy successor of Ghani Bey, whose oppressions are recorded in Mr. Holme Beaman’s interesting book on the Near East, Fehim has been, and is still,, the object of the hatred and terror of all Turkish subjects. His gor­geous carriage, with its yellow upholstery, is one of the sights of Pera as it rolls swiftly down the Grande Roe, with his Ex­cellency seated pompous'y in it—a fat and short man with a decidedly unpleasant cast of countenance. His rival at Coart is Nejib Melbame (or Malfame, to quote a Perote nick­name) and both have distinguished them­selves by their seal in hatching and revealing the same plots ! Fehim is more daring than the conning Syrian ; possibly because he feels himself more secure. Twice, at night, he has striven to get sympathy at Yildiz by the singularly risky method of dropping from this same gorgeous vehicle a bomb timed to ex­plode when his person was sufficiently removed from danger. This served another purpose. It was intended to prove the existence of conspiracy, to* discover which Fehim and Mal- fame had received a commission. Malfame was the first to be commissioned. He miraculously unearthed a nest of bombs and conspirators and after ransacking every nook and corner, he assured the Sultan that he might repose in absolute tranquillity. This would not do for Fehim, who, to upset the Saltan’s confidence in his rival, resorted to the barbarous method above described. Perhaps it was a coincidence, but strange to relate the outrages presumably attempted on his person took place soon after the mysterious removal from Top Hana of several of the bombs which Malfame had found. Q E D. It remains to be seen what punishment the Saltan will mete oat to his foster son, to appease the wrath of the in­dignant German Elchi—possibly some promo­tion to the provinces and a subsequent restora­tion to Imperial favour.

THE POST OFFICE FRAUDS

Yesterday, an interesting development oc­curred in the startling case of the forgery of foreign money orders through the Egyptian Post Office. When the Florio-Rubattino S.S. Singapore arrived at Alexandria from Naples it was boarded by the Alexandria police, who at once arrested one of the passengers, on the charge of having acted as accomplice on the continent of Europe in farthering the machina tions of the person who styled himself “George Bey,’’ in attempting to enoash money orders to the extent of £20,000. The man, when seized by the police, gave his name as Zinos Velis.

The history of the discovery of this fraud is very interesting, and reflects great credit on the Egyptian Postal Administration for so promptly following up the matter. A telegram was received last week at the General Post Office at Alexandria from the post office at Milan announcing the arrival of an unusual number of foreign money orders from Egypt and asking whether they were to be cashed. This telegram was followed by others sent from the postal authorities at Rome, Brussels, and Berne couched in similar terms. The issue of the orders was stated to have taken place on the 22nd ulto.

The Postmaster General thereupon entrusted Borton Bey with a mission of enquiry, and that official left for Cairo on Thursday. It was discovered that there had been a most serious fraud committed, for the European post offices had wired the serial numbers of the money orders. Farther enquiries pointed to a certain Georgiadis, a clerk in the Cairo post office, as being the guilty party It was found that he was nominally on sick leave at Helouan. When his whereabouts were sought after there no trace of him was discovered. Telegrams were then sent to the Italian General Post Office at Rome with orders to arrest such a man, as he was presumably following the money orders in order to encash them. A telegram was received at the General Post Office at Alexandria on Friday night announcing that the Italian authorities had effected the arrest at Naples of a man of the name of “George Bey.” Further telegrams arrived here on Saturday from Naples stating that the man, who bad been arrested, had admitted that his real name was Georgiadis, and that he was a postal clerk at Cairo.

A number of the money orders bad been ad­dressed to a certain Zanos, and another official enquiry was opened to discover the whereabouts of this person, but this was cleared up by a telegram from Italy to the effect that a man of that name had embarked , on the Fiorio-Rubattino S.S. Singapore, which was due to arrive at Alexandria yesterday; The arrest was effected, as we have announced, and as Zanos is a local subject be was handed over to the Egyptian authorities and interro- gated by the Parquet this morning. He admitted to the Parquet that he was employed by Georgiades.
Georgiadis, who is a Hellenic subject, bears an excellent character in his official capacity,
and was recognised as a quiet, respectable, hard-working postal employe.

The total amount involved was £20,000 and it is satisfactory to know that nothing has been paid over. The fraud was executed on the 23rd ulro. and by yesterday, the 3rd inst., both the men implicated were in gaol in various parts of the world. The Egyptian postal authorities are to be congratulated on the celerity with which they followed up the indications they received from Europe.

SAVOY HOTEL.
SATURDAY’S FESTIVITIES.

Few outside invitations had been issued for Saturday’s dance at the Savoy; but the house is so crowded, and there were such a number of dinner parties arranged for that night, that the ball-room and lounge were patronized to their full later on in the evening. Every avail¬able table was occupied in the dining-room and restaurants, the overflow being accom¬modated in the covered-in verandah. Sir Ernest Cassel was one of the hosts of the evening, having Lady Newborough and Mrs. Cassel among his party. Mrs. Leverioh had a large party, and among the other hosts were Dr. Tribe, Mr. and Mrs. Cochrane, Mr. Phillipson, Mrs. and Miss Bennett, Count and Countess Hellnstein, Biron Pfyffer, Baron Bleich-iTfor, Baron Biederman, M. and Mme Cordonier, Mr. and Miss Pooley, Mr. Wigham, etc. The sexett orchestra discoursed very gentle music during the dinner hour, and the Ladies’ Orchestra did their duty bravely during the remainder of the evening. The latter has improved wonderfully daring the last few weeks, and if most people will insist upon waltzes which grow faster and faster, there are many dancers now who are learning the charm of a slow dance to a quick measure.

No one looked better than the Countess of Hellnstein in a wonderful dress of yellow draped with fine lace about the shoulders,whioh lace hung in long ends from the back of the elevated waist line. Mrs Wain was with her two daughters,the eldest looking very well in a plain princess frock of yellow satin, and Miss Blythe locked extremely handsome in a beautiful frock of pale green. Miss Shaw had on a dainty frock of spotted net over pale pink, many garlands of pink ribbon ruching trimming both skirt and bodice, and Miss Molloy was in a dress of grey chiffon taff tas. he soft corsage being of much betnek- ed chiffon of the same shade. GHEZIREH PALACE.
A SUCCESSFUL DANCE.

Ghszireh Palace Hotel has more than its usual complement of smart visitors this year, and the dance on Thursday evening attracted many of the residents in the neighbourhood as well as a goodly assortment from Cairo. OPERA HOUSE STRIKE.

* The strike of the fourteen musicians at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, is the talk of the Capital. According to their version, they had counted on extra earnings to make ends meet, such, for instance, as a series of classic concerts at the Cercle Artistique. M. Poncet objected; whence the defection. The Cairote Press deals with the question from points of view characteristic of their respective opinion. “L’Egypte” is opposed to all arbitrary measures adopted against the strikers, and wonders that such incidents have not taken place before, in view of the antecedents of the direotor of the troupe.
“L’Orient” counsels moderation, and an appeal to the good offices of M. le Consul de France. It apmpathises with M. Poncet, and absolves him of all blame.
The “Journal da Caire” writes in the same strain.

“L’Africaine” afforded as all the keenest delight—quite apart from the undoubter merit of M. Meyerbeer’s music. That charm¬ing vessel rolling, on its obvious pivots, even as the “Umberto Primo” rolls off the Cretan coast, the desolate mien of the crew huddled close to the bulwark-*, M. Mezy's sustained and despairing clutch at the mast, the while he shouted in sonorous frenzy, the wild incursion and alarm at the end —as of porters and boatmen in Naples harbour all was a joy, tinged with hope of “leave” to come or reminiscence of leave enjoyed. Even the cabin hangings which M. Fontaine brushed aside as he came and went were a memory of bathrooms and cabins, poignant and vivid. Yet no “Rubattino” or other boat could find its wild way to that weird island peopled with high- priests of the Brahmin persuasion, ballet- dancers, and, last of all, savages in sumptuous armour and European boots : those of course they had footed from the late departed crew of the ill-fated ship. Oh ! most exquisite island, most romantic ship!

The opera itself was performed much as usual, not without vigour and inaccuracy. Mile. Devillay, though, was really delicious. M. Fontaine seems to take to the fort tenor” parts, and enjoys his high notes. He is really a fine actor and musician. What a pity his voice is so displeasing ! He deserves a better fate. The orchestra, it appears, was “on strike,” bat it was hard to notice any great difference, except that there were fewer and less prominent discords. M. Archimbaud would probably do quite well with two men and a boy, instead of the recalcitrant band he fails to control.
ABBAS THEATRE.

There were two really had episodes in “Mefitofele” : the chorus in the prologue was appalling, and in the second part Signora Orbellini gave an entirely wrong rendering of the ‘Elena” music. The “La luna piena’ should be, vocally, as cold, as dear, as rippling as the words are themselves. She treated it as she would have treated “La Tosca.” However, her voice in itself is charming, the mistake was technical only. The only other fault was a certain want of cohesion in the garden scene; but Signor Lucenti saved the situation.

With these exceptions, it was really finely given. The conductor knows the opera, he handles his orchestra with a splendid keen vigour and intellectually, which one appre­ciates after Signor Archimbaud’s listless,almost careless, treatment. Signor Battani, for all he has a bad cold, was exquisite; one could only just detect a certain slight huskiness ; and be seemed disinclined to take any notes higher th>n a natural He took them all the same once or twice. Signa. Fabris was nervous until the 3rd act. In that she was faultless; she sang with all the sweetness, passion, and dramatic power the scene requires. And Signor Lucenti ! He was not Signor Lucenti, he was Mifitofele incarnate. He conveyed every least shade of irony, sarcasm, scathing contempt that Bolto has put into the part; and his voice is a thing to dream of.—a superb full bass, resonant, never harsh, never a hair-breadth off the note. The part could not have been better sung. We have heard Signor Walter in the pain 1904-1905 and he evidently gave it finely this season at Alexandria. But Signor Lucenti puts his rendering, fine as it is, entirely into the shade. The prologue—where we forgot all the evil discords of the chorus, the “Fischio fischio” song in all its utter contempt for. God and man, the whole of the Brocken scene, the mocking, disgusted,disdainfal satire of “Questa Attica Terra,” and the finale where the fiend descends, vanquished, but still great and contemptuous -one can find no words for these. I think if the Alexandria critic had heard it, he would hava changed bis opinion of Bolto and bis opera. Many, it is true, —many eminent musicians as well—think little enough of Bolto : they say he cannot orchestra, his effects shadowy, his scenes badly arranged, hie methods old-fashioned and poor. Bat the fact remains that "Mefistofele,” for all it failed in 1868. is now given all over- Italy, as well as in London and Faris, and that ‘Mefistofele” had as much influences as the work of Verdi himself on Italian opera. And really the beauty of the 3rd act, of the “Fisohio” song, of the Greek underworld scene, and the weird declamation on the Brocken, do deserve acknowledgment. Of course, Bolto under-orchestrates; he only wrote that one opera. How should he learn in one opera t< handle orchestras. He is an experimentalistwith no sort of wish to turn out 30 or 40 big pieces of work ; he is an analyst and a poet the whole of the libretto is taken from the original legend. He owes nothing to Gounod, and only a certain amount to Goethe himself his reading is totally different. All through the music, too, he experiments : he has special instruments and orchestration for Mefistofele- the "equilli” and certain pizzicato effects- and for Faust, usually violins and a certain soft and more melodious suavity. Of course, the whole work must be carefully given and properly staged. The Brocken scene, the Greek scene, the “Si gira, si gira” chorus, all have their absurd side; but so have many great operas. Anyone who heard M. Zuccani do the “Tannhauser” overture in waltz time will acknowledge that. Signor Lucenti, by the way is from La Scala, and is considered to be on of the three finest basses in Italy. The “Abbas is treating ns well, in that several others of the troupe are prominent performers at Milan, Naples, and other great opera towns.
